12.13.22  3:35 pm   it's my birthday today (13th dec), i'm 16 now, and life has no meaning

      in that case, it looks like you are in for a pleasant surprise

12.13.22  2:47 pm   would you be able to share an audio journal from a year ago today?

      sure

12.13.22  2:00 pm   are you a frog

      no, thank you for checking

12.13.22  1:57 pm   Which of your songs had alternate titles, and what were they?

      i don't have a complete list because it would be too ambiguous, and many of them are just subtle doubts of whether to include tiny words like "the" or "a", etc. but some highlights may include:
       "it's the first day of school" == "might quit"
       "special sandals" == "fly around"
       "getting ready to" / "beautiful day" / ... just about every other line of the song before i found the right one == "the ending"
       "money (cash)" or "got some money" == "money"
       "the easter bunny told me that christmas isn't real (but santa claus is still jesus)" == "christmas isn't real"

      the world flag. i'm not sure if there is an official world flag, but just about any rendition of a flag that represents the world, i am on board with that one

      to dazzle and inspire you

12.13.22  7:03 am   How do record the music I hear in my dreams? Like seriously, I hear nice music in my dreams but at the moment I wake up, I forgot everything. It's frustrating.

      i think if you make a habit of working on music frequently enough, eventually, hopefully, you will forget to notice whether you are awake or asleep. and you'll be able to bridge this gap, even if just for fleeting moments

12.12.22  10:26 pm   Could you share your rules of capital letter usage?

      it's not perfectly defined, but some of the general principles are: chord symbols are always capitalized (except for "b" when it's used to mean "flat"). Acronyms are almost always capitalized. the letter L is often capitalized whenever it would otherwise be in danger of being confused for I or 1. the letter "i" when referrring to self is never capitalized. the start of sentences may occasionally need to be capitalized if i feel there is a tone change, or if there should be a decisive break in between sentences, OR if there seems to be a lot of other punctuation in the area and it would otherwise be unclear that it's the start of a new sentence. It's used for emphasis, the same way bold would be used, and the reason i prefer capitals instead of bold is because it's much more likely that the capitals will actually show up on any device, where as bold might get lost somehow. And also if i'm just simply referring to the letter itself, such as the letter F, it is most often capitalized, because that is probably the way that most people think of individual letters. The exception to that, of course, would be the letter "i", which, again, for similar reasons to why L sometimes gets capitalized more often, "i" should be capitalized less often because, similarly, it runs the risk of being confused with l or 1. I also often use capitalization for signage, especially with short contents, such as "STOP" or "EXIT", especially when i am trying to replicate signage that people are familiar with in the outside world
